function.description: The user can enter their height in feet and inches, centimeters, or meters.
The user can enter their weight in pounds or kilograms.
The user can choose between imperial (feet/inches, pounds) and metric (centimeters/meters, kilograms) units.
The system calculates the BMI based on the provided height and weight.
The calculated BMI value is displayed clearly to the user.
The system provides an interpretation of the BMI result (e.g., Underweight, Normal weight, Overweight, Obese) based on standard BMI categories.
The user can clear the input fields to enter new height and weight values.
The system handles invalid inputs (e.g., non-numeric values, zero height) gracefully and provides appropriate error messages.
The page is accessible to users with disabilities, following accessibility guidelines (e.g., ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation).
The page is responsive and adapts to different screen sizes (desktops, tablets, mobile phones).

Allows employees to submit claims for Travel, Labor, Management, and Equipment expenses.
Enables employees to choose the appropriate expense category (Travel, Labor, Management, or Equipment).
Allows employees to input details such as date, amount, description, and attach supporting documents (receipts, invoices, etc.).
Enables employees to view the status (Pending, Approved, Rejected) of their submitted claims.
Allows employees to edit claims that are in 'Pending' status.
Allows employees to view all their previously submitted claims and their corresponding details.
Allows user to download a summary of their approved claims.
Displays a list of all expense claims awaiting approval.
Allows the administrator to approve or reject individual expense claims.
Requires the administrator to provide a reason when rejecting a claim.
Allows the administrator to view all details of a specific expense claim, including attachments.
Allows the administrator to filter claims by category, status, employee, and date range.
Allows administrator to download a report of all claims, filtered claims, or claims within a specific date range (e.g., CSV, Excel).
Allows administrator to set budget limits for each expense category (Travel, Labor, Management, Equipment).
Displays a comparison of budgeted amounts against actual expenses for each category.
Provides a visual representation (charts, graphs) of budget variances, highlighting areas where spending exceeds or falls short of the budget.
Allows administrator to generate a report showing budget limits, actual spending, and variances for each category.

Allows administrator to assign roles (Employee, Administrator) to users.
Allows administrator to deactivate or activate user accounts.

Allows users to remove a preferred product from a customer's record.
Allows users to view the purchase history for a specific customer.
Allows users to add new product records to the system, including name, category, and recommended price.
Allows users to view and edit existing product records, including all associated details.
Allows users to delete product records from the system (with appropriate confirmation).
Allows users to search for products by name, category, or other relevant criteria.
Allows users to create new purchase records, linking them to a specific customer, product, datetime, quantity, and amount.
Allows users to view and edit existing purchase records, including all associated details.
Allows users to delete purchase records from the system (with appropriate confirmation).
Allows users to search for purchase records by customer, product, date range, or other relevant criteria.
Allows administrators to view sales data aggregated by product, showing total quantity sold and revenue generated.
Allows administrators to view sales data aggregated by product category, showing total quantity sold and revenue generated.
Allows administrators to view sales data aggregated by customer, showing total purchase amount and number of purchases.
Allows administrators to view sales trends over a specified time period (e.g., daily, weekly, monthly).
Allows administrators to identify the top selling products based on quantity sold or revenue generated.
Allows administrators to identify the top customers based on total purchase amount or number of purchases.
Allows administrators to generate reports on sales data, which can be filtered by various criteria (e.g., product, customer, date range).
Allows administrators to export sales data in a common format (e.g., CSV, Excel) for further analysis.
Allows authorized users to log in to the system with their credentials.
Allows logged-in users to securely log out of the system.
Allows users to reset or change their passwords.
Allows administrators to create, manage, and delete user accounts with different roles and permissions.
The page should display the text 'helloworld'.

Reads the 'Spring Semester Subjects.xlsx' file from the specified directory.
Verifies that the Excel file has the expected headers: '#', 'Name', 'Weekday', 'Time'.
Ensures that the 'Time' column only contains valid values: 'First period', 'Second period', 'Third period', 'Fourth period'.
Transforms the data into a two-dimensional subject table (matrix) where rows represent weekdays and columns represent time periods.
Fills the subject table with subject names based on the 'Weekday' and 'Time' values from the input Excel file.
Defines the behavior if multiple subjects are scheduled for the same weekday and time period (e.g., display error, select one subject).
Creates a new Excel file (name configurable) to store the transformed subject table.
Writes the two-dimensional subject table to the newly created Excel file, with appropriate weekday and time period headers.
Applies formatting to the output Excel file (e.g., column widths, font, borders) for readability.
Saves the transformed data to the specified Excel file (e.g., 'Subject Schedule.xlsx').
Handles the error when the input Excel file is not found.
Handles the error when the input Excel file does not have the expected headers.
Handles the error when the 'Time' column contains invalid values.
Handles the error when multiple subjects are scheduled for the same weekday and time period.
Handles the error when the output Excel file cannot be created or written to.
Reads the data from the specified Excel file.
Replaces missing values (NaN) with the mean of the respective column for numeric columns, and the mode for non-numeric columns.
Creates a one-period lag of the 'result' variable (result_lagged).
Defines the dependent variable (result_lagged) and independent variables (all other columns).
Prepares the data by selecting the independent and dependent variables and adding a constant to the independent variables.
Fits a logistic regression model using the prepared data.
Generates a summary of the fitted logistic regression model.
Saves the summary of the logistic regression model to an Excel file named Logistic.xlsx.
Catches any potential errors during the process and prints an error message.
Begins a new crawl with a randomly generated character and initial location.
Loads a previously saved game state from a file.
Displays helpful information about the game, controls, and gameplay mechanics.
Quits the game.
Moves the character one tile in the specified direction. Obstacles or enemies may block movement.
Displays a description of the current location, including any visible items, enemies, or features.
Displays a list of items currently carried by the character.
Displays information about the character, such as health, attack, defense, and experience.
Saves the current game state to a file.
Returns to the main menu.
Adds an item from the current location to the character's inventory.
Removes an item from the character's inventory and places it in the current location.
Activates the effect of an item. The specific effect depends on the item type (e.g., healing potion, weapon).
Equips a wearable item (e.g., armor, helmet) from the inventory, providing stat bonuses.
Removes an equipped item.
Initiates an attack on a visible enemy in the current location.
Attempts to escape from combat by moving to a random adjacent location (may fail).

Allows the player to interact with special features in the current location, such as talking to NPCs, opening chests, or activating switches. The interaction may trigger events, provide information, or reward the player.
Reads the 'Deathlist.csv' file containing death records.
Extracts the 'Date of death' field from each record.
Parses the 'Date of death' string into a date object (if necessary for processing).
Groups the death dates into weekly intervals (Monday-Sunday or similar).
Counts the number of deaths within each weekly interval.
Generates a histogram visually representing the number of deaths per week.  The X-axis represents weeks and the Y-axis represents the death count.
Prints the histogram to the console (likely as a text-based representation if not using external libraries).
Formats the histogram output for readability (e.g., scaling the histogram, adding labels, etc.).
Checks if the 'Deathlist.csv' file exists before attempting to read it.
Handles errors that may occur while reading the CSV file (e.g., invalid format, corrupted data).
Handles errors that may occur when parsing the 'Date of death' field (e.g., invalid date format).
Deals with missing or null values in the 'Date of death' field.
